I was first introduced to the [b] mobile version [/b] of this game and had been playing it for a few months before finding out about the Steam version. Honestly, I was quite [b]elated[/b] to learn about the Steam version and proceeded to download and play it immediately.

To borrow part of my review of the mobile version, I feel like this game is very [b] ingenious [/b] and [b] original [/b]. I love the creative liberties taken in this game and I love how diverse the dialogues and girls are. I also really like all the [b] Easter Eggs [/b] quite prevalent in the game even if I don't know all of them because they're quite easy to pick up on. The [b] reset mechanic [/b] is also the first of its kind in any game I've ever played, and it really is a nifty one, giving us the chance to re-experience budding romances with our favourite and memorable girls.

The UI (User Interface) is also quite superb. Everything is easy to access and navigate to, and I especially like how big everything is because I am visually impaired. Therefore, my UX (User Experience) is also very positive overall. This game does possess some nostalgia as it takes me back to the click games I used to play as a child (obviously not like this game, but children's games. Lol!). Even though all you do is click, I find myself playing this game for quite a length of time. I also like how a lot can be left up to the imagination of the player. I like imagining the settings I'd be in when interacting with the girls. I really like the supersize and wider aspect ratio of some of the photos in the album compared to the mobile view.

[spoiler]I also love how the voices are automatically included in this version, whereas in the mobile version they have to be purchased with diamonds, and while not as comprehensive as in the main game, I especially love that there are even voices in the parallel world events, whereas in the mobile version there's just silence[/spoiler].

Considering that this version was released [b] 3 years prior to the mobile version [/b], I won't critique it for what it lacks. All in all, I have the same wonderful experience playing this version as I do the mobile one, even if it relies more on making purchases to acquire additional girls. It's a small price to pay anyway. I'll afford them all one day. But, all in all, a really great game. I even re-downloaded it after deleting it from mobile a couple of times because there was initially very little appeal, but now I'm here to stay. Maybe this version is even better because of its UI on larger screens. But, both have unique advantages to them, and I'll keep playing both for as long as the games run.

Been "playing" for roughly 15.8 hours. 273/458 unlocks. Some unlocks are hidden behind paying diamonds or money to unlock specific characters. The price is not a rip-off. Lots of the events will feature NSFW scenes as well if you reach specific stages (usually the last stage). It's hit or miss if you like it or not. The writing for the scenes is short but good.

Everything can be done by the diamonds you get and the dev gives you "daily check-ins" that unlock a diamond and gives you a boost, usually 1-8 hour job boost or hobby boost, which helps (hint: boost wisely). So first played this over a decade ago on an ecchii website called Nutaku (or something). Only for a bit, never got too far with it. Then the Nintendo Switch release came out, and I loaded it up on my Switch out of pure curiousity

Decided to grab it, again, here because I remember finding it fairly amusing. With me giggling a fair amount when going through the Switch version

.... aaaaaaaaannnnndddd....

Well, heads up, the games dialogue is a bit dated. Not in any way that it makes sense for the cancel police to go after it (well, there are lesbians in the game, so the ACTUAL Cancel Culture will not like this game)

More... uh... think about Disco Stu for a bit. How the whole point of that character is to be a bit of dated pastiche of sorts. Like a character who dresses like it is Victorian Times or the Renessance Faire (Steam Punk too, I guess?)--except we view Disco Stu as a bit less classy than those two other examples. The writing in this game is like a 2010s version of Disco Stu

Now, if you are given a heads up going on in, the jokes have a bunch more leeway--and the game is surprisingly enjoyable still

I'm playing it more as a bit of a naughty comedy where I'm going at it for more some of the jokes (most of them silly and innoculous--nothing socialological in nature). I don't know how people going in wanting to play a game with a single hand would handle it. I cannot see myself doing that too much--but that is more a personal thing

Fun little bit of a time waster, that I likely will be throwing more money at--because it generates various of the Happy Brain Chemicals(TM) and I need more of those. Even if it means reading stuff that has the dialogue that is like the 2010s version of Disco Stu

Not really a game you put any real effort into--I would say Hush Hush is more of the game by this studio that involves any form of thought required on the players part

Oh gosh, right--one of the weird 2010s-ism is the notion that people generally don't think of Red Pandas when thinking about Pandas, and instead think of those liar Bears that are not actually Pandas.Panda Bears aren't actual Pandas--they just look like Pandas. Think like how Panda Whales got called "Whale Killers" and then "Killer Whales"--even though Panda Whales is the more accurate, albeit more antiquated, term for them. It is just stuff like that, which reminds you this game was made back in precedented times. Nothing upsetting--just "oh right yeah, that was a thing people use to say"

I look forward to putting some bees towards this game. Bees are what we called Nickels way back when we tied an onion onto our belt--as was the fashion. On account of the nickels having a picture of a bee on them

negative.review:
Honestly, a shame. There's some really good stuff in here but it's just... not fun. Not as a dating sim, not as an idle game, I guess the poarn element is kind of nice because of the buildups. And it looks great! The girls are pretty. And are all of age, which is... ugh. Why do I have to write this.

Anyway. What I particularly liked is that while they're still pretty shallow stereotypes that do not map very well on actual women, at least they aren't Japanese copypastes of poarnish archetypes. And some of them are really, really weird. You can date a bear. An actual female bear, not even made animu cute. A realistic, female bear. Yes, you can have sex with her, too.

So instead of having a tsundere, loli, oneesan, etc etc you have such classics as "basic beach beetch", gamer girl, cat girl, sporty girl...  except the way they're written, I kinda want to say that the writer never talked to a woman before. The gamer girl's entire personality is the fact that she's a gamer (an early 2010s gamer to be exact), there's a hot teacher who behaves pretty much like a roleplay persona, there's an actual incarnation of a fapgame site, and the sporty girl is literally Rainbow Dash from my My Little Pony. You can really tell when this game was made, and by who. I won't say it doesn't have a certain charm to it, though.

What's kinda vexing about writing is that there are also "phone flings" (think texting simulator, with waiting and saucy pics), and some of these actually read like real flirting? Some. They're actually my favourite part of the game; you can think of them as mini visual novels. And hoo boy, there are so many. Same with the girls, to be honest. So many. I can't imagine what sort of poly saturation point you'd need to be able keep up with this many partners! Or maybe if your day consisted of 96 hours...?

Tbh, that might be what's going on. Since this is an idle game, you're constantly given more "time blocks" which define how much stuff you can do at once. Before you know it, you'll work 5 jobs, do 6 hobbies and go on dates all at once. This kinda breaks the flow of how usual dating sims work, where you slowly turn from a bottom-feeding loser to Her-Acles, the slayer of Lernean Puss. Here you just kind of... get everything, and eventually need to get even more everything because it's an idle game.

FREE TO PLAY PLAYERS BEWARE ! ! You are eventually going to hit a hard wall because this game has a finite amount of the currency needed to progress.

I have over 390 hours in this game, so I think I‚Äôve seen pretty much everything it has to offer for free. Crush Crush starts off fun: the characters are nice, the writing is cute and campy, and the idle mechanics are satisfying at first. But after a while, the game play eventually boils down to endless repetition and paywalls. Progression reaches a snails pace not long into the game as you're obligated to wait several hours in between milestones - which would be okay if you eventually GOT to the milestones, but much of the time your wait period is something like 15 years because you need to use time boosts which - you guessed it - cost money. The free premium currency is extremely limited, so eventually you just hit a wall and cant go any further if you don't pay for more diamonds to boost your stats. It's quite discouraging to get almost 400 hours into a game and be told there's no way for you to progress without money.

I won't lie to you though - this game is doing well. But despite nearly a decade of success, the developers refused to update the game‚Äôs dated and sometimes low quality visuals. Instead of hiring new artists or refreshing the look, they just keep recycling old assets, drawing over top of them, and expecting people to pay for it.

Meanwhile, they invest tons of money on other project's artwork (for example: hiring Nanoless, a very talented and expensive artist) while Crush Crush stays the exact same. The event girls feel very half-baked and are usually just re-colors of old art with a few things drawn over top of them. Further, if you miss a single event day, you can‚Äôt get the final reward unless you pay for diamonds. You're literally one and done. To me, it just feels like the devs care more about milking the game than improving it.

Free game and easy to play, a never ending clicker game, but I don't have the patience anymore. It's the worst time consuming game I've ever seen. And at the end, it's not even worth it. I've played soooo muuch just to get 0.1% progress. 
I'm not a fan of the art, so getting a "pic" of the girls in bikini, idc. 
Me, who like to tryhard nsfw games for the steam achievements, I'm not gonna spend a second on this cookie clicker anymore. Launching this game (with blush blush) was a mistake. 
Because playing a game to grind it, to this point, when there is no fun left, for what ? Even if there is a some kind of end game, I would skip it. 

Plus, the "gameplay", if you can call it that. Per example, you'll need to give 314 roses to a girl, but oooh sadness when you see you cannot choose how much gifts you can give because it is a set value. 
Give her more you tell me ? Mmmh, not when the gift cost you 95 trillions and you gain 13 trillions over 7 days. 

To play this, you need to skip real time by changing the time of your computer (or other technique) because who the hell wants to wait 56 days for an upgrade ? And an auto-clicker of course, or else gl.

I felt more ease getting into this one strangely enough. At first progression felt a bit hard, but then as I was getting a bit higher on the bonuses from resetting it had felt "easier". It slowly took a divebomb into being the most frustrating and tedious task, just getting all the girls you can up and then just losing EVERYTHING to only get an extremely small bonus the next time. Not including me buying the DLC on sale, I had spent about $30 just getting two x64 boosts and one x2 boost. I would've bought them sooner or just quit the game entirely if I had realized before spending 80 hours on the game that I was getting absolutely nowhere. After buying the two 64x and one 2x boosts I only had to play for a few weeks before FINALLY AFTER YEARS PLAYING THIS GAME ON MULTIPLE PLATFORMS AND DESPERATELY WANTING TO FINISH IT that I was able to get all my hobbies to max and finish the game. It will be frustrating if you try to finish this game without paying especially if you're like me who can't open the game everyday for the daily bonuses. This game is a waiting game and has you restarting over for what feels like a million times will probably make you want to crash out. I can't really say it was worth it aside from the characters looking cute. It's free though, so don't let me stop you from hitting the "Add to Library" button or "Play Game" button.

FREE TO PLAY PLAYERS BEWARE ! ! You are eventually going to hit a hard wall because this game has a finite amount of the currency needed to progress.

I have over 390 hours in this game, so I think I‚Äôve seen pretty much everything it has to offer for free. Crush Crush starts off fun: the characters are nice, the writing is cute and campy, and the idle mechanics are satisfying at first. But after a while, the game play eventually boils down to endless repetition and paywalls. Progression reaches a snails pace not long into the game as you're obligated to wait several hours in between milestones - which would be okay if you eventually GOT to the milestones, but much of the time your wait period is something like 15 years because you need to use time boosts which - you guessed it - cost money. The free premium currency is extremely limited, so eventually you just hit a wall and cant go any further if you don't pay for more diamonds to boost your stats. It's quite discouraging to get almost 400 hours into a game and be told there's no way for you to progress without money.

I won't lie to you though - this game is doing well. But despite nearly a decade of success, the developers refused to update the game‚Äôs dated and sometimes low quality visuals. Instead of hiring new artists or refreshing the look, they just keep recycling old assets, drawing over top of them, and expecting people to pay for it.

Meanwhile, they invest tons of money on other project's artwork (for example: hiring Nanoless, a very talented and expensive artist) while Crush Crush stays the exact same. The event girls feel very half-baked and are usually just re-colors of old art with a few things drawn over top of them. Further, if you miss a single event day, you can‚Äôt get the final reward unless you pay for diamonds. You're literally one and done. To me, it just feels like the devs care more about milking the game than improving it.

Because playing a game to grind it, to this point, when there is no fun left, for what ? Even if there is a some kind of end game, I would skip it.

For male players, do, not play. This game will only leave you in deeper despair and inevitable sorrow. Save your time and dignity, when real women await you.

Honestly, a shame. There's some really good stuff in here but it's just... not fun. Not as a dating sim, not as an idle game, I guess the poarn element is kind of nice because of the buildups. And it looks great! The girls are pretty. And are all of age, which is... ugh. Why do I have to write this.

Anyway. What I particularly liked is that while they're still pretty shallow stereotypes that do not map very well on actual women, at least they aren't Japanese copypastes of poarnish archetypes. And some of them are really, really weird. You can date a bear. An actual female bear, not even made animu cute. A realistic, female bear. Yes, you can have sex with her, too.

So instead of having a tsundere, loli, oneesan, etc etc you have such classics as "basic beach beetch", gamer girl, cat girl, sporty girl...  except the way they're written, I kinda want to say that the writer never talked to a woman before. The gamer girl's entire personality is the fact that she's a gamer (an early 2010s gamer to be exact), there's a hot teacher who behaves pretty much like a roleplay persona, there's an actual incarnation of a fapgame site, and the sporty girl is literally Rainbow Dash from my My Little Pony. You can really tell when this game was made, and by who. I won't say it doesn't have a certain charm to it, though.

What's kinda vexing about writing is that there are also "phone flings" (think texting simulator, with waiting and saucy pics), and some of these actually read like real flirting? Some. They're actually my favourite part of the game; you can think of them as mini visual novels. And hoo boy, there are so many. Same with the girls, to be honest. So many. I can't imagine what sort of poly saturation point you'd need to be able keep up with this many partners! Or maybe if your day consisted of 96 hours...?

Tbh, that might be what's going on. Since this is an idle game, you're constantly given more "time blocks" which define how much stuff you can do at once. Before you know it, you'll work 5 jobs, do 6 hobbies and go on dates all at once. This kinda breaks the flow of how usual dating sims work, where you slowly turn from a bottom-feeding loser to Her-Acles, the slayer of Lernean Puss. Here you just kind of... get everything, and eventually need to get even more everything because it's an idle game.

But it's not a particularly good idle game. It lacks this... hook. This thing that makes you want to make the number go up. Sure, wanting to see some titties might be a motivator, but I feel like it doesn't mix well with the idle gameplay. And since you'll also have to prestige to get anywhere, you'll have absolutely nothing for a significant amount of time, and then you'll unleash the boobonic plague. Although that's kinda how it is in life for some reason, so... points for, uh, realism?...

Still. It's free, and while there technically are microtransactions, the game's relatively generous with freebies and there's no gacha mechanics whatsoever. To have the fun fun version you need to pay - I had a pass from when I tried to play Cabin Fever (which I also didn't like), so I figured, hey, why not this one a go. Mixed feelings.
